results.title: Crafts in Yackandandah
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Inspired by the changing landscape, the availability of raw materials and a sense of community, various talented crafts practitioners call Yackandandah home. From internationally recognised potter John Dermer and local weaver Jan Clements, to Christine Thorpe owner of Spiritus Gallery we are introduced to wood carvers, guitar makers and jewellery designers.
results.description: Inspired by the changing landscape, the availability of raw materials and a sense of community, various talented crafts practitioners call Yackandandah home. results.title: Crafts in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Australia Council and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This is a semi-promotional film made for the Crafts Council of Australia. Shows Australian craftsmen and women and their ideas, motivation and life style. Mirka Mora briefly features.

results.title: Cradle To The Grave (1994)
results.brief_description: Released in 1994, Cradle To The Grave was the music video for rap group Thug Life’s latest single. It commented on racial politics and incarceration in the America.

constellations_other.name: Confronting injustice on-screen
constellations_other.description: The Black Lives Matter movement and the treatment of African Americans at the hands of authorities is explored in this Constellation that connects hip-hop, the Civil Rights Movement and representation in Hollywood.

results.description: Released in 1994, Cradle To The Grave was the music video for rap group Thug Life’s latest single. It commented on racial politics and incarceration in the America.

results.title: Crackpot, jackpot: Human contrasts and survival
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Botanic man”.
This program takes a look at the problems caused by the high energy consumption of modern countries and some possible solutions. It contrasts life in California, the inhabitants of a tower block who live in a completely controlled environment and the inhabitants of Mexico where Indians are farming land which is rich in oil and great changes are about to embrace them.

results.title: Cracking the stone age code
results.creator_credit: David Collison, Paul Johnstone and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Examines the work of Alexander Thom, former professor of engineering science at Oxford, whose investigations into stone circles and standing circles of Britain threaten to upset prehistoric knowledge. We see him at work in Scotland, and then go to Britain to see how his findings apply there.

results.title: Cracking the egg
results.brief_description: A comprehensive look at eggs. Considers the variations in size shape, texture and structure. Notes the origins of the egg, how it forms, the incubation differences by parent birds, hatching and the fate of the residual shell. Also touches on the so called bionic egg, egg collecting, the domestication of wildfowl, the egg’s place in folklore, its uses in the culinary arts, its influence in the decorative arts, the egg marketing industry, Easter eggs and artificial eggs.
